I'll keep the letter as a precaution.

senses.definition: a way of referring to contraception

examples.x: We didn't take any precautions and I got pregnant.

senses.definition: done in order to prevent problems or to avoid danger

examples.x: He was kept in the hospital overnight as a precautionary measure.

senses.definition: the ability to react quickly and stay calm in a difficult or dangerous situation

examples.x: The boy had the presence of mind to turn off the gas.

senses.definition: a strong metal pot with a tight lid (= cover), that cooks food quickly by steam under high pressure
a situation that is difficult or dangerous because people are likely to become anxious or violent

examples.x: I needed to get away from the pressure cooker atmosphere of the campus during finals week.
They performed wonders in keeping the lid on the pressure cooker of a rapidly rising jail population.

senses.definition: an object whose name you do not use because you do not need to or want to, or because you do not know it

examples.x: Can you pass me that thing over there?
She's very fond of sweet things (= sweet foods).
He's just bought one of those exercise things.
Turn that thing off while I'm talking to you!

senses.definition: an object that is not alive in the way that people and plants are

examples.x: Don't treat her like that—she's a person, not a thing!
He's good at making things with his hands.
She took no interest in the people and things around her.
Books may one day become a thing of the past (= something that no longer exists).
I need to buy a few basic things like bread and milk.

senses.definition: objects, clothing or tools that belong to somebody or are used for a particular purpose things

examples.x: Shall I help you pack your things?
Bring your swimming things with you.
I'll just clear away the breakfast things.
Put your things (= coat, etc.) on and let's go.

senses.definition: a fact, an event, a situation or an action; what somebody says or thinks thing

examples.x: They talked about many things, like books, music and films.
There are a lot of things she doesn't know about me.
There's another thing I need to tell you.
Bad things happen to good people.
I've got lots of things to do today.
He has things on his mind.
The most important thing in life is to have fun!
She said the first thing that came into her head.
Forgetting her was the only thing in the world I found I couldn't do.
He found the whole thing (= the situation) very boring.
Let's forget the whole thing (= everything).
Among other things, I have to deal with mail and keep the accounts.
I like camping, climbing and that sort of thing.
‘Why did you tell her our secret?’ ‘I did no such thing!’
There's no such thing as a typical day in this job.
One thing is for sure—it will be a memorable evening!
The main thing to remember is to switch off the burglar alarm.

senses.definition: the general situation, as it affects somebody situation

examples.x: Things haven't gone entirely to plan.
I wish things could have been different.
Hi, Jane! How are things?
As things stand at present, he seems certain to win.
All things considered (= considering all the difficulties or problems), she's done very well.
They're trying to change things for the better.
Things have changed over the last few years.
He's happy with the way things have worked out.
Why do you make things so difficult for yourself?

senses.definition: a quality or a concept

examples.x: Reality and truth are not the same thing.
The two of them have one thing in common—they never give up.
The good thing about this job is all the travelling.

senses.definition: what is needed or socially acceptable

examples.x: You need something to cheer you up—I know just the thing!
to say the right/wrong thing
The best thing to do is to apologize.

senses.definition: used to say that something is important or real

examples.x: I don't understand why these corny films are still a thing in 2020.
I'm not sure that ‘modular techno music’ is really a thing.

senses.definition: used with negatives to mean ‘anything’ in order to emphasize what you are saying

examples.x: I haven't got a thing to wear!
She hasn't had a thing to eat all day.
There wasn't a thing we could do to help.
Ignore what he said—it doesn't mean a thing.

senses.definition: all that can be described in a particular way

examples.x: She loves all things Japanese.

senses.definition: a living creature

examples.x: All living things are composed of cells.

senses.definition: used to talk to or about a person or an animal, to show how you feel about them

examples.x: You silly thing!
You must be starving, you poor things.
The cat's very ill, poor old thing.
The baby's a pretty little thing.

senses.definition: to use your hands, arms or body in order to make somebody/something move forward or away from you; to move part of your body into a particular position

examples.x: We pushed and pushed but the piano wouldn't move.
Push hard when I tell you to.
You push and I'll pull.
She pushed at the door but it wouldn't budge.
He walked slowly up the hill pushing his bike.
Somebody pushed me and I fell over.
When you push the gate, it doesn't open.
She pushed the cup towards me.
He pushed his chair back and stood up.
I tried to hug him but he pushed me away.
She pushed her face towards him.
I pushed the door open.

senses.definition: to use force to move past somebody/something using your hands, arms, etc.

examples.x: People were pushing and shoving to get to the front.
The fans pushed against the barrier.
Try and push your way through the crowd.

senses.definition: to press a switch, button, etc., for example in order to make a machine start working

examples.x: I pushed the button for the top floor.
The operator must have accidentally pushed the switch on the joystick.
She pushed a lever and the machine responded.
Push the red button to open the doors.

senses.definition: to affect something so that it reaches a particular level or state

examples.x: This development could push the country into recession.
The rise in interest rates will push prices up.
Little pent-up demand exists to push the economy forward this year.
The surplus has helped push world prices to as little as 55 euros per tonne.
Such a huge population increase will continue to push food prices higher.
Rising inflation pushes down real interest rates.

senses.definition: to persuade or encourage somebody to do something that they may not want to do

examples.x: He made it clear that he would resist any attempt to push him into early retirement.
My teacher pushed me into entering the competition.
No one pushed you to take the job, did they?

senses.definition: to make somebody work hard

examples.x: The music teacher really pushes her pupils.
Lucy should push herself a little harder.
He keeps pushing himself to get better.

senses.definition: to put pressure on somebody and make them angry or upset

examples.x: Her parents are very tolerant, but sometimes she pushes them too far.
He felt he was being pushed to the limit of his self-control.

senses.definition: to try hard to persuade people to accept or agree with a new idea, buy a new product, etc.

examples.x: The interview gave him a chance to push his latest movie.
She didn't want to push the point any further at that moment.
He continues to push his own political agenda.
Sales promotion is designed to push certain products.
The two governments are pushing for economic reform in the region.
They're pushing hard for a ban on GM foods.

senses.definition: to sell illegal drugs
to move forward quickly through an area

examples.x: The army pushed (on) towards the capital.

senses.definition: an area of soft wet ground

examples.x: The heavy rain soon turned the field into a quagmire.

senses.definition: a difficult or dangerous situation
deep wet sand that you sink into if you walk on it
a situation that is dangerous or difficult to escape from
showing a lack of care about danger and the possible results of your actions Reckless

examples.x: He showed a reckless disregard for his own safety.
She was a good rider, but reckless.
to cause death by reckless driving
She threw herself into the game with reckless abandon.
He had always been reckless with money.

senses.definition: in a way that shows a lack of care about danger and the possible results of your actions

examples.x: He admitted driving recklessly.
She had fallen hopelessly and recklessly in love.

senses.definition: a situation in which you are prepared for something dangerous to happen; a warning of this

examples.x: Following the bomb blast, local hospitals have been put on red alert.
The water authority has issued a red alert until the cause of the pollution has been removed.

senses.definition: a flag used to warn people of danger

examples.x: You mustn’t swim when the red flag is flying.

senses.definition: a sign that something is not right or something bad may happen

examples.x: Teachers need to be alert to the red flags that signal children are experiencing difficulties.

senses.definition: a red flag as a symbol of revolution or communism
shelter or protection from danger, trouble, etc.

examples.x: A further 300 people have taken refuge in the US embassy.
The region was a place of refuge for outlaws and bandits.
They were forced to seek refuge from the fighting.
As the situation at home got worse she increasingly took refuge in her work.

senses.definition: a place, person or thing that provides shelter or protection for somebody/something

examples.x: The marshes are a wetland refuge for seabirds, waders and wild fowl.
He regarded the room as a refuge from the outside world.

senses.definition: a building that provides a temporary home for people in need of shelter or protection from somebody/something

examples.x: The best option for a female victim of domestic abuse is to contact a women's refuge.
During the great fire of 1871 the church served as a refuge for people who were homeless.

senses.definition: an area in the middle of a road where you can stand and wait for cars to go past until it is safe for you to cross
to save somebody/something from a dangerous or harmful situation save

examples.x: The coastguard rescued six people from the sinking boat.
The woman was rescued from her burning home by firefighters.
You rescued me from an embarrassing situation.
The house was rescued from demolition.
He rescued a child from drowning.
The hostages were rescued and brought to safety.
The shelter rescues stray dogs.
She had despaired of ever being rescued alive.

senses.definition: the act of saving somebody/something from a dangerous or difficult situation; the fact of being saved

examples.x: We had given up hope of rescue.
A wealthy benefactor came to their rescue with a generous donation.
a rescue operation/mission
a mountain rescue team
rescue helicopters/boats/workers
The United Nations is helping to coordinate rescue efforts.

senses.definition: an occasion when somebody/something is saved from a dangerous or difficult situation

examples.x: Ten fishermen were saved in a daring sea rescue.
Her own boat capsized after she attempted a rescue.

senses.definition: a dog that has been rescued after being treated badly

examples.x: Anyone thinking of buying a dog should think about adopting a rescue dog.

senses.definition: a dog that is trained to take part in rescue operations

examples.x: Training a search and rescue dog can take as long as three years.

senses.definition: a person who saves somebody/something from a dangerous or harmful situation

examples.x: Rescuers began to free the trapped miners.

senses.definition: a person whose job is to try to save people from dangerous or difficult situations, especially after an accident or a disaster

examples.x: Rescue workers are working under very difficult conditions to find survivors from the blast.

senses.definition: the possibility of something bad happening at some time in the future; a situation that could be dangerous or have a bad result

examples.x: The health risks are very low.
a high risk of failure
a serious/significant risk of something
The study found a slightly increased risk of cancer in this group.
Steps have been taken to reduce the risk of any trouble.
Use filters or boil water to minimize the risk of infection.
Smoking can increase the risk of developing heart disease.
There is still a risk that the whole deal will fall through.
The chemicals pose little risk (= are not dangerous) to human health.
a calculated risk (= one that you think is small compared with the possible benefits)
Trying new things can be a gamble, but it's worth the risk.
Patients should be made aware of the risks involved with this treatment.
Make sure you understand the risks and benefits.
Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for this disease.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is likely to cause problems or danger at some time in the future

examples.x: Those old boxes in the corridor are a fire risk.
a safety/health risk
The group was considered to be a risk to national security.
Pollutants in the river pose a real risk to the fish.

senses.definition: a person or business that a bank or an insurance company is willing/unwilling to lend money or sell insurance to because they are likely/unlikely to pay back the money, etc.

examples.x: With five previous claims, he's now a bad insurance risk.
He's a good insurance risk.

senses.definition: to put something valuable or important in a dangerous situation, in which it could be lost or damaged

examples.x: He risked his life to save her.
She was risking her own and her children's health.
He risked all his money on a game of cards.
They were willing to risk everything for their liberty.

senses.definition: to do something that may mean that you get into a situation which is unpleasant or harmful for you

examples.x: There was no choice. If they stayed there, they risked death.
These families risked losing everything.
I can't risk anyone telling my parents about it.

senses.definition: to do something that you know is not really a good idea or may not succeed

examples.x: He risked a glance at her furious face.
They risked the wrath of the government (= risked making them angry) by leaking the story.
It was a difficult decision but we decided to risk it.
I knew I would be in trouble if I was found out, but I decided to risk it anyway.
We've been advised not to risk travelling in these conditions.

senses.definition: not willing to do something if it is possible that something bad could happen as a result Risk-averse

examples.x: We live in a risk-averse culture.
In business you cannot be innovative and risk-averse at the same time.

senses.definition: the practice of doing things that involve risks in order to achieve something
something that is designed to protect people from harm, risk or danger

examples.x: Stronger legal safeguards are needed to protect the consumer.
The measures have been introduced as a safeguard against fraud.

senses.definition: something that you do in order to prevent something bad or dangerous from happening
to travel on water using sails or an engine sail

examples.x: to sail into harbour
The dinghy sailed smoothly across the lake.
The ferry sails from Newhaven to Dieppe.
one of the first people to sail around the world
The flotilla will sail north to Hawaii.
to sail the Atlantic
In his young days he had sailed the seas.

senses.definition: to control or travel on a boat with a sail, especially as a sport

examples.x: We spent the weekend sailing off the south coast.
Do you go sailing often?
the first woman to sail solo around the world
She sails her own yacht.
He managed to sail the boat between the rocks.

senses.definition: to begin a journey on water

examples.x: We sail at 2 p.m. tomorrow.
He sailed for the West Indies from Portsmouth.
The ferry sails for Southampton at 5.30.

senses.definition: to move quickly and smoothly in a particular direction; (of people) to move in a confident manner

examples.x: clouds sailing across the sky
The ball sailed over the goalie's head.
She sailed past, ignoring me completely.
An owl sailed silently out of the branches.
